raw_text: We use AuToBI? s models, which were trained on the spontaneous speech Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), to identify prosodic events in our corpus
clean_text: We use AuToBI's models, which were trained on the spontaneous speech Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), to identify prosodic events in our corpus.

raw_text: Note that, in order to transcribe the test data ,wehave trained a 20 Gaussian per state 39 MFCC Hidden Markov Model speech recognizer with HTK, using the training and development sets together with TIMIT (Fisher et al, 1986), the Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), and the Columbia Game Corpus (Hirschberg et al, 2005)
clean_text: Note that, in order to transcribe the test data, we have trained a 20 Gaussian per state 39 MFCC Hidden Markov Model speech recognizer with HTK, using the training and development sets together with TIMIT (Fisher et al, 1986), the Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), and the Columbia Game Corpus (Hirschberg et al, 2005).

raw_text: Expert discourse structure analyses are used to derive CONSENSUS SEGMENTATIONS, consisting of discourse boundaries whose coding all three labelers agreed upon (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996)
clean_text: Expert discourse structure analyses are used to derive CONSENSUS SEGMENTATIONS, consisting of discourse boundaries whose coding all three labelers agreed upon (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996).

citing_paper_authors: Swapna, Somasundaran | Janyce, Wiebe | Paul, Hoffmann | Diane J., Litman
raw_text: Speech was found to improve inter-annotator agreement in discourse segmentation of mono logs (Hirschberg and Nakatani 1996)
clean_text: Speech was found to improve inter-annotator agreement in discourse segmentation of monologues (Hirschberg and Nakatani 1996).

citing_paper_authors: Marco, Carbone | Ya'akov, Gal | Stuart M., Shieber | Barbara J., Grosz
raw_text: Most previous work that has combined multiple annotations has used linear segmentations ,i.e. dis course segmentations without hierarchies (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996)
clean_text: Most previous work that has combined multiple annotations has used linear segmentations, i.e. discourse segmentations without hierarchies (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996).

citing_paper_authors: Marco, Carbone | Ya'akov, Gal | Stuart M., Shieber | Barbara J., Grosz
clean_text: A conservative way to combine segmentationsinto a gold standard is the Consensus (CNS) (or raw agreement) approach (Hir chberg and Nakatani, 1996).

raw_text: Discourse structure has been successfully used in non-interactive settings (e.g. understanding specific lexical and prosodic phenomena (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), natural language generation (Hovy, 1993), essay scoring (Higgins et al, 2004) as well as in interactive settings (e.g .predictive/generative models of postural shifts (Cassell et al., 2001) ,generation/interpretation of anaphoric expressions (Allen et al, 2001), performance modeling (Rotaru and Litman, 2006))
clean_text: Discourse structure has been successfully used in non-interactive settings (e.g. understanding specific lexical and prosodic phenomena (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), natural language generation (Hovy, 1993), essay scoring (Higgins et al, 2004) as well as in interactive settings (e.g. predictive/generative models of postural shifts (Cassell et al., 2001), generation/interpretation of anaphoric expressions (Allen et al, 2001), performance modeling (Rotaru and Litman, 2006)).

citing_paper_authors: Vivek Kumar, Rangarajan Sridhar | Srinivas, Bangalore | Shrikanth S., Narayanan
raw_text: Wereport results on the Boston University (BU) Radio Speech Corpus (Ostendorf et al, 1995) and Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (HirschbergandNakatani, 1996), two publicly available speech corpora with manual ToBI annotations intended for experiments in automatic prosody labeling
clean_text: We report results on the Boston University (BU) Radio Speech Corpus (Ostendorf et al, 1995) and Boston Directions Corpus (BDC) (Hirschberg and Nakatani, 1996), two publicly available speech corpora with manual ToBI annotations intended for experiments in automatic prosody labeling.

citing_paper_authors: Fan, Yang | Peter A., Heeman | Andrew, Kun
raw_text: In spontaneous monologue, Butterworth (1972) found that the beginning of a discourse segment exhibited slower speaking rate; Swerts (1995), and Passonneau and Litman (1997) found that pause length correlates with discourse segment boundaries; Hirschberg and Nakatani (1996) found that the beginning of a discourse segment correlates with higher pitch
clean_text: In spontaneous monologue, Butterworth (1972) found that the beginning of a discourse segment exhibited slower speaking rate; Swerts (1995), and Passonneau and Litman (1997) found that pause length correlates with discourse segment boundaries; Hirschberg and Nakatani (1996) found that the beginning of a discourse segment correlates with higher pitch.
